I'm bullish on $BTC  In Bitcoin, ‚Äú #Shrimps  ‚Äù refers to small retail investors who hold relatively small amounts of BTC. Individually they may seem insignificant, but collectively they matter a lot. Shrimps tend to buy consistently, often during fear and uncertainty, providing steady demand when larger players hesitate. Over time, their accumulation helps absorb supply, stabilize price action, and build strong market foundations. History shows that major Bitcoin cycles often begin quietly with shrimps accumulating long before whales and institutions make their moves. Because of this narrative, I find the #Shrimps  meme token idea very valuable. This movement represents all investors.

A lot of beginners think Bitcoin is ‚Äúold tech.‚Äù
That‚Äôs not the full picture.


Bitcoin keeps trending on CoinMarketCap because it plays a very specific role in the crypto market.


Unlike many newer projects, $BTC was designed to be simple: a decentralized, limited-supply digital asset. That simplicity is exactly why many people see it as a reference point for the entire market.


When Bitcoin moves or trends, it often reflects broader market sentiment, not hype, but attention, caution, or confidence.


For beginners, understanding Bitcoin isn‚Äôt about price prediction.
It‚Äôs about learning why scarcity, security, and long-term trust still matter in digital finance.


Not financial advice. Always take time to learn and research.

Global debt is acceleration continues

In Q3 2025 alone, worldwide debt increased by roughly $8 trillion, pushing total global debt to a new record near $346 trillion. Developed economies now carry about $231 trillion in debt, while emerging markets have climbed to an all-time high of around $115 trillion.

The U.S. and China together drove almost a third of that quarterly increase.

Zooming out, the scale becomes clearer. Over the first three quarters of 2025, global debt expanded by about $26.4 trillion, which works out to roughly $677 billion added every single week.

As a result, the global debt-to-GDP ratio has risen to around 310 percent, the highest level since early 2024.

It‚Äôs not a sudden shock, but a steady buildup. And it‚Äôs one of those background forces shaping markets whether people are talking about it or not

This doesn‚Äôt tell you direction tomorrow. It tells you that the people with the longest time horizon are getting more comfortable at these levels.

You may hear some people say ‚ÄúBitcoin is a scam‚Äù, especially from those who have lost significant money in crypto. Often, these claims come from lack of knowledge, poor strategy, or frustration with others profiting while they struggle. History, however, tells a very different story.

Bitcoin and Ethereum have gone through massive corrections. Bitcoin has fallen 50‚Äì70% multiple times, and Ethereum dropped nearly 90% in 2018, going from $830 to around $85. During these periods, critics claimed crypto was a scam, but over time, Bitcoin recovered and reached new all-time highs. 

It‚Äôs also important to remember that around 20% of Bitcoin is lost forever in inaccessible wallets. Additionally, Bitcoin has a maximum supply of 21 million coins, making it a deflationary asset. Its scarcity, combined with adoption and utility, gives it long-term value.  Remember this.
